conclusion: To determine whether the light will be totally reflected when it is emitted from the inside of the sphere, we need to analyze the situation step by step using the principles of optics, specifically Snell's Law and the concept of total internal reflection.
A beam of light is incident from air onto the sphere at point A with an angle of incidence i.
When light enters the transparent medium (sphere), it bends according to Snell's Law: n_air sin(i) = n_sphere sin(r).
n_air is the refractive index of air (approximately 1), n_sphere is the refractive index of the sphere, i is the angle of incidence, r is the angle of refraction inside the sphere.
As i increases, r also increases, but r is always smaller than i because n_sphere > n_air.
The refracted light travels inside the sphere and reaches point B, where it strikes the inner surface of the sphere.
At point B, the light is incident on the sphere's inner surface with an angle i' (the angle between the light ray and the normal at point B).
Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of incidence i' at point B exceeds the critical angle θ_c, which is given by: θ_c = arcsin(n_air / n_sphere).
n_air is the refractive index of air, n_sphere is the refractive index of the sphere.
If i' > θ_c, the light will be totally reflected inside the sphere instead of refracting out into the air.
The angle i' depends on the initial angle of incidence i at point A and the geometry of the sphere.
As i increases, i' also increases. For sufficiently large i, i' can exceed the critical angle θ_c.
When i is large enough, the angle i' at point B can exceed the critical angle θ_c.
If i' > θ_c, the light will undergo total internal reflection at point B and will not refract out of the sphere.
Yes, when the incident angle i is large enough, the light will be totally reflected when it is emitted from the inside of the sphere.
